title: On the Complexity of CSP-based Ideal Membership Problems

sections.our contribution:
In this paper we expand on  and [ref]7  in several ways. We consider IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) for languages Î“Î“\Gamma over arbitrary finite set and attempt to obtain general results about such problems. However, we mainly focus on a slightly different problem than ProblemÂ 1.1. For which constraint languages Î“Î“\Gamma the problem IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) [or IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma)] can be solved in polynomial time? Note that answering whether f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0} belongs to a certain ideal does not necessarily mean finding an ideal membership proof of that. However, we will argue that, firstly, in many applications this is the problem we need to solve and therefore our results apply. Secondly, in SectionÂ 6.3 we will show that in the majority of cases if the existence of an ideal membership proof can be efficiently decided, such a proof can also be efficiently found. Firstly, in SectionÂ 3 we study reductions between IMPâ€™s when the language Î“Î“\Gamma is enlarged in certain ways. Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a constraint language over a set Dğ·D. By Î“âˆ—superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{*} we denote Î“Î“\Gamma with added constant relations, that is, relations of the form {(a)}ğ‘\{(a)\}, aâˆˆDğ‘ğ·a\in D. Imposing such a constraint on a variable xğ‘¥x essentially fixes the allowed values of xğ‘¥x to be ağ‘a. First, we prove that adding constant relations does not change the complexity of the IMP. For any Î“Î“\Gamma over Dğ·D the problem IMPâ€‹(Î“âˆ—)IMPsuperscriptÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma^{*}) is polynomial time reducible to IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma), and for any dğ‘‘d the problem IMPdâ€‹(Î“âˆ—)subscriptIMPğ‘‘superscriptÎ“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma^{*}) is polynomial time reducible to IMPd+|D|â€‹(|D|âˆ’1)â€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘ğ·ğ·1Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d+|D|(|D|-1)}(\Gamma). TheoremÂ 1.3 has two immediate consequences. Since IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) is in co-NP, for any CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma) instance ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} there is always a proof that the input polynomial f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0} does not belong to the ideal Iâ€‹(ğ’«)Iğ’«\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}). Any solution of ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} that is not a zero of f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0} will do. Finding such a proof may be treated as a search version of IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma). Through self-reducibility, TheoremÂ 1.3 allows us to solve the search problem. Let Î“Î“\Gamma be such that IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) [IMPd+|D|â€‹(|D|âˆ’1)â€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘ğ·ğ·1Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d+|D|(|D|-1)}(\Gamma)] is solvable in polynomial time. Then for any instance (f0,ğ’«)subscriptğ‘“0ğ’«(f_{0},\mathcal{P}) of IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) [IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma)] such that f0âˆ‰Iâ€‹(ğ’«)subscriptğ‘“0Iğ’«f_{0}\not\in\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}), a solution ğšğš\mathbf{a} of ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} such that f0â€‹(ğš)â‰ 0subscriptğ‘“0ğš0f_{0}(\mathbf{a})\neq 0 can also be found in polynomial time. TheoremÂ 1.3 also provides a hint at a more plausible conjecture for which languages Î“Î“\Gamma the problem IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) or IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) is polynomial time. In particular, it allows to find an example of Î“Î“\Gamma such that CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma) is tractable while IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) is not, even for a Î“Î“\Gamma on a 2-element set and d=1ğ‘‘1d=1. Later we state some results that might indicate that IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) is polynomial time for every Î“Î“\Gamma such that CSPâ€‹(Î“âˆ—)CSPsuperscriptÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma^{*}) is polynomial time. Note that the structure of such CSPs is now very well understood. Another way of expanding a constraint language is by means of primitive-positive (pp-) definitions and pp-interpretations, and it is at the core of the so-called algebraic approach to the CSP. A relation Rğ‘…R is said to be pp-definable in Î“Î“\Gamma if there is a first order formula Î¦Î¦\Phi using only conjunctions, existential quantifiers, equality relation, and relations from Î“Î“\Gamma that is equivalent to Rğ‘…R. Pp-interpretations are more complicated (see SectionÂ 3.3) and allow for certain encodings of Rğ‘…R. Let Î“,Î”Î“Î”\Gamma,\Delta be constraint languages over the same set Dğ·D, Î”Î”\Delta is finite, and every relation from Î”Î”\Delta is pp-definable in Î“Î“\Gamma. Then IMPâ€‹(Î”)IMPÎ”\textsc{IMP}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) and IMPdâ€‹(Î”)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î”\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) for any dğ‘‘d. Let Î“,Î”Î“Î”\Gamma,\Delta be constraint languages, Î”Î”\Delta is finite, and Î”Î”\Delta is pp-interpretable in Î“Î“\Gamma.
Then there is a constant kğ‘˜k such that IMPdâ€‹(Î”)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î”\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to IMPkâ€‹dâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘˜ğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{kd}(\Gamma) for any dğ‘‘d. The approach of TheoremÂ 1.5 was first applied to various proof systems in , although that work is mostly concerned with proof complexity rather than computational complexity. Mastrolilli  ventured into pp-definability without proving any reductions. In particular, the first part of TheoremÂ 1.5 uses techniques from  for projections of ideals. It will later allow us to develop further universal algebra techniques for the IMP. The second part of that theorem will also work towards more powerful universal algebra methods. Recall that according to  in order to find an SOSÂ proof one needs to be able to find Nullstellensatz proofs efficiently. The reductions from TheoremsÂ 1.3, 1.5 do not always allow to recover such a proof efficiently only confirming such a proof exists, and therefore cannot be directly used in the conditions from . However, in SectionÂ 7 we address this issue. Recall that a polymorphism of a constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma over a set Dğ·D is a multi-ary operation on Dğ·D that can be viewed as a multi-dimensional symmetry of relations from Î“Î“\Gamma. By Polâ€‹(Î“)PolÎ“\textsf{Pol}(\Gamma) we denote the set of all polymorphisms of Î“Î“\Gamma. As in the case of the CSP, TheoremÂ 1.5 implies that polymorphisms of Î“Î“\Gamma is what determines the complexity of IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma). In SectionÂ 4.1 we show the following. Let Î“,Î”Î“Î”\Gamma,\Delta be constraint languages over the same set Dğ·D, Î”Î”\Delta is finite. If Polâ€‹(Î“)âŠ†Polâ€‹(Î”)PolÎ“PolÎ”\textsf{Pol}(\Gamma)\subseteq\textsf{Pol}(\Delta), then IMPâ€‹(Î”)IMPÎ”\textsc{IMP}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) and IMPdâ€‹(Î”)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î”\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) for any dğ‘‘d. CorollaryÂ 1.6 allows us to represent IMPs through polymorphisms and classify the complexity of IMPs according to the corresponding polymorphisms. The method has been initiated by Mastrolilli and Bharathi [ref]7  , although mainly for 2- and one case of 3-element sets. We apply this approach to obtain three sufficient conditions for tractability of the IMP. Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a constraint language over a set Dğ·D. Then if one of the following conditions holds, IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) is polynomial time solvable for any dğ‘‘d. Î“Î“\Gamma has the dual-discriminator polymorphism (i.e.Â a ternary operation gğ‘”g such that gâ€‹(x,y,z)=xğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¥g(x,y,z)=x unless y=zğ‘¦ğ‘§y=z, in which case gâ€‹(x,y,z)=yğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¦g(x,y,z)=y); Î“Î“\Gamma has a semilattice polymorphism (i.e.Â a binary operation fğ‘“f such that fâ€‹(x,x)=xğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥f(x,x)=x, fâ€‹(x,y)=fâ€‹(y,x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘¦ğ‘¥f(x,y)=f(y,x), and fâ€‹(fâ€‹(x,y),z)=fâ€‹(x,fâ€‹(y,z))ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¦ğ‘§f(f(x,y),z)=f(x,f(y,z))); |D|=pğ·ğ‘|D|=p, pğ‘p prime, and Î“Î“\Gamma has an affine polymorphism modulo pğ‘p (i.e.Â a ternary operation hâ€‹(x,y,z)=xâŠ–yâŠ•zâ„ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§direct-sumsymmetric-differenceğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§h(x,y,z)=x\ominus y\oplus z, where âŠ•,âŠ–direct-sumsymmetric-difference\oplus,\ominus are addition and subtraction modulo pğ‘p, or, equivalently, of the field ğ–¦ğ–¥â€‹(p)ğ–¦ğ–¥ğ‘\mathsf{GF}(p)). In this case every CSP can be represented as a system of linear equations over ğ–¦ğ–¥â€‹(p)ğ–¦ğ–¥ğ‘\mathsf{GF}(p). The three polymorphisms occurring in TheoremÂ 1.7 have played an important role in the CSP research. For one reason they completely cover the tractable cases when |D|=2ğ·2|D|=2 and therefore the results of  , although we used some results (on semilattice polymorphisms) from . For the first part of TheoremÂ 1.7 (also known as 0/1/all constraints) we come up with a technique of preprocessing the input polynomial f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0} that allows us to get rid of permutation constraints and greatly simplify the proof for the dual-discriminator polymorphism, including the special case |D|=3ğ·3|D|=3 considered in [ref]7. In the second part of TheoremÂ 1.7 we use the fact, see , that any language with a semilattice polymorphism is pp-interpretable in a language on a 2-element set also having a semilattice polymorphism. Then TheoremÂ 1.7(2) follows from TheoremÂ 1.5(2) and the results of . As is mentioned, the third part of TheoremÂ 1.7 is in fact about systems of linear equations over ğ–¦ğ–¥â€‹(p)ğ–¦ğ–¥ğ‘\mathsf{GF}(p), since every instance of CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma), where Î“Î“\Gamma has an affine polymorphism, is equivalent to a system of linear equations over ğ–¦ğ–¥â€‹(p)ğ–¦ğ–¥ğ‘\mathsf{GF}(p). Bharathi and Mastrolilli solved this case for p=2ğ‘2p=2 showing that IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) is polynomial time for any dğ‘‘d. Their approach is based on FGML algorithm  to construct a bounded degree GrÃ¶bner Basis. Instead, we map an instance of IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) on a different domain consisting of pğ‘p-th roots of unity rather than {0,â€¦,pâˆ’1}0â€¦ğ‘1\{0,\dots,p-1\}. This transforms the generators of the ideal into very simple polynomials that form a GrÃ¶bner BasisÂ without any further modifications. Such a transformation makes it difficult to find an ideal membership proof, but this is resolved in SectionÂ 6.3. In SectionÂ 4.2 we prove that the standard features of the universal algebraic approach to the CSP work for IMPÂ as well. These include reductions for standard algebraic constructions such as subalgebras, direct powers, and homomorphic images. They easily follow from TheoremÂ 1.5(2). A more general construction of direct product requires a more general version of CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma), and therefore of IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma), the multi-sorted one, in which every variable can have its own domain of values. We do not venture into that direction in the paper. One implication of these results is a necessary condition for tractability of IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) that follows from a similar one for the CSP. In the second part of the paper we consider a number of applications of the techniques developed in the first part. The key to those applications is an extension of the IMP defined as follows. Given an ideal IâŠ†ğ”½â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]Iğ”½subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\emph{{I}}\subseteq\mathbb{F}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}] and a vector of â„“â„“\ell polynomials M=(g1,â€¦,gâ„“)ğ‘€subscriptğ‘”1â€¦subscriptğ‘”â„“M=(g_{1},\dots,g_{\ell}), the Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ asks if there exist coefficients ğœ=(c1,â€¦,câ„“)âˆˆğ”½â„“ğœsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“superscriptğ”½â„“\mathbf{c}=(c_{1},\dots,c_{\ell})\in\mathbb{F}^{\ell} such that ğœâ€‹M=âˆ‘i=1â„“ciâ€‹giğœğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1â„“subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–\mathbf{c}M=\sum_{i=1}^{\ell}c_{i}g_{i} belongs to the ideal I. As with the regular IMP, Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ can be parametrized by specifying a constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma, in which case the resulting problem Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMP(Î“)Î“(\Gamma) (or Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMP(Î“)d{}_{d}(\Gamma) if the degree of input polynomials is bounded) only allows ideal produced by instances of CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma). We prove that Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ can be solved in polynomial time when a (dğ‘‘d-truncated) GrÃ¶bner BasisÂ can be efficiently generated, and also admits the same reductions as the IMP. Let Î“,Î”Î“Î”\Gamma,\Delta be constraint languages and Î”Î”\Delta is finite. Then If every relation from Î”Î”\Delta is pp-definable in Î“Î“\Gamma, then Ï‡â€‹IMPâ€‹(Î”)ğœ’IMPÎ”\chi\textsc{IMP}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to Ï‡â€‹IMPâ€‹(Î“)ğœ’IMPÎ“\chi\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) and Ï‡â€‹IMPdâ€‹(Î”)ğœ’subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î”\chi\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to Ï‡â€‹IMPdâ€‹(Î“)ğœ’subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\chi\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) for any dğ‘‘d. If Î”Î”\Delta is pp-interpretable in Î“Î“\Gamma,
then there is a constant kğ‘˜k such that Ï‡â€‹IMPdâ€‹(Î”)ğœ’subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î”\chi\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Delta) is polynomial time reducible to Ï‡â€‹IMPkâ€‹dâ€‹(Î“)ğœ’subscriptIMPğ‘˜ğ‘‘Î“\chi\textsc{IMP}_{kd}(\Gamma) for any dğ‘‘d. The theorem above allows us to show that for every Î“Î“\Gamma for which IMPdâ€‹(Î“)subscriptIMPğ‘‘Î“\textsc{IMP}_{d}(\Gamma) is polynomial time solvable, so is Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMP(Î“)d{}_{d}(\Gamma). This includes constraint languages invariant under dual-discriminator, semilattice, and affine polymorphisms. In SectionÂ 6.3 we use Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ along with the factor ring ğ”½â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]/Iğ”½subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›I\mathbb{F}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}]/\emph{{I}} modulo an ideal I to generate a basis for the factor ring consisting of monomials of degree at most dğ‘‘d, and then use it to construct a dğ‘‘d-truncated GrÃ¶bner BasisÂ for I. More precisely, we prove the following. Let â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} be a class of ideals for which Ï‡â€‹IMPdğœ’subscriptIMPğ‘‘\chi\textsc{IMP}_{d} is polynomial time solvable. Then there exists a polynomial time algorithm that constructs a degree dğ‘‘d GrÃ¶bner BasisÂ of an ideal Iâˆˆâ„‹Iâ„‹\emph{{I}}\in\mathcal{H}, IâŠ†ğ”½â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]Iğ”½subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\emph{{I}}\subseteq\mathbb{F}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}], in time Oâ€‹(nd)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘O(n^{d}). TheoremÂ 1.9 makes it possible to construct dğ‘‘d-truncated GrÃ¶bner BasesÂ in all cases IMPâ€‹(Î“)IMPÎ“\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) is known to be polynomial time. Thus, it basically eliminates the gap between deciding the existence of an ideal membership proof and finding such a proof. We apply Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ and algebraic techniques to finding Sum-of-Squares (SoS) proofs. For variables x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\dots,x_{n} a semialgebraic set is given by a collection of polynomial equalities and inequalities such as The goal is to proof that some polynomial râ€‹(ğ±)ğ‘Ÿğ±r(\mathbf{x}) is nonnegative on Sğ‘†S. An SOSÂ proof of râ€‹(ğ±)â‰¥0ğ‘Ÿğ±0r(\mathbf{x})\geq 0 is given by a polynomial identity of the form The degree of an SOSÂ proof is often defined to be the maximum degree of the polynomials involved in the proofs i.e., maxâ¡{dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(hi2),dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(sj2â€‹qk),dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(Î»iâ€‹pi)}ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\max\{deg(h_{i}^{2}),deg(s_{j}^{2}q_{k}),deg(\lambda_{i}p_{i})\}. If the degree is bounded such a proof can often be found using an SDP program. We obtain two results related to SOSÂ proofs. The first one deals with the recently discovered issue of high bit complexity of such proofs. Oâ€™Donnell  discovered that in some cases although an SOSÂ proof of low degree exists, it may involve exponentially long coefficients, and therefore it may be impossible to find such a proof efficiently. Raghavendra and WeitzÂ  suggested three conditions such that if the set Sğ‘†S satisfies them, the existence of a low degree SOSÂ proof implies the existence of a low bit complexity one. In SectionÂ 7.2 we show that for sets Sğ‘†S in which the polynomials p1,â€¦,pmsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{1},\dots,p_{m} are produced from some CSP instance of the form CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma) one of these conditions (Î´ğ›¿\delta-richness) is guaranteed to be true, and another one (kğ‘˜k-effectiveness) can be dropped altogether. Then if rğ‘Ÿr has a degree dğ‘‘d SOSÂ proof of nonnegativity on Sğ‘†S, it also has a degree dğ‘‘d SOSÂ proof of nonnegativity with coefficients bounded by 2pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(nd,logâ¡1Îµ)superscript2ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘1ğœ€2^{poly(n^{d},\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon})}. In particular, if there are no polynomial inequalities then every coefficient can be written down with only pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(nd)ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘poly(n^{d}) bits. The second result concerns the degree bounds that are required for the SOSÂ proof system to be automatizable. An SOSÂ proof is clearly divided into the â€œideal partâ€, a combination of p1,â€¦,pmsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{1},\dots,p_{m} that belongs to the corresponding ideal and the â€œSOSÂ partâ€ (the rest). The standard requirement is that maxâ¡{dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(hi2),dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(sj2â€‹qk),dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(Î»iâ€‹pi)}ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\max\{deg(h_{i}^{2}),deg(s_{j}^{2}q_{k}),deg(\lambda_{i}p_{i})\} has to be bounded in order for SOSÂ to be automatizable. We show that this requirement can be relaxed so that only maxâ¡{dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(hi2),dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(sj2â€‹qk)}ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\max\{deg(h_{i}^{2}),deg(s_{j}^{2}q_{k})\} is bounded, provided the ideal generated by p1,â€¦,pmsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{1},\dots,p_{m} belongs to a tractable Ï‡â€‹IMPâ€‹(Î“)ğœ’IMPÎ“\chi\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma). Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a constraint language such that Ï‡â€‹IMPâ€‹(Î“)ğœ’IMPÎ“\chi\textsc{IMP}(\Gamma) is polynomial time decidable. Then for a polynomial rğ‘Ÿr, the existence of an SOSÂ proof (1) with maxâ¡{dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(hi2),dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(sj2)}â‰¤dğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—2ğ‘‘\max\{deg(h_{i}^{2}),deg(s_{j}^{2})\}\leq d is polynomial time decidable. The above theorem could potentially improve upon the existing SOSÂ SDP relaxations for several problems. For instance, problems such as Vertex Cover, Clique, and Stable Set, are all instances of Boolean CSPs for which the corresponding Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ is polynomial time decidable. More generally, Ï‡ğœ’\chiIMPÂ is polynomial time decidable for the 2-SAT problem, hence polynomial optimization problems over 2-SAT can enjoy the more relaxed version of SOSÂ proofs introduced in Theorem 1.11. An interesting research direction would be studying the power of this relaxed setting in terms of approximation algorithms. Finally, in SectionÂ 8, we apply our techniques to show that the theta bodies  arising from certain combinatorial problems can be constructed in polynomial time. One of the core problems in optimization is to understand the convâ€‹(S)convğ‘†\texttt{conv}(S) or a relaxation of convâ€‹(S)convğ‘†\texttt{conv}(S), where Sğ‘†S the set of feasible solutions to a given problem and convâ€‹(S)convğ‘†\texttt{conv}(S) denotes the convex hull of Sğ‘†S. Here, we consider combinatorial ideals arising from CSPs where Sğ‘†S is a finite subset of â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}. Theta body relaxations, introduced by Gouveia, Parrilo and Thomas , obtain a hierarchy of relaxations to convâ€‹(S)convğ‘†\texttt{conv}(S). They are strong relaxations, for instance, they achieve the best approximation among all symmetric SDPs of a comparable size  and are known to have nice properties . Let Tâ€‹Hkâ€‹(Iâ€‹(ğ’«))ğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜Iğ’«TH_{k}(\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P})), ğ’«âˆˆCSPâ€‹(Î“)ğ’«CSPÎ“\mathcal{P}\in\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma), denote the kğ‘˜k-th theta body of Iâ€‹(ğ’«)Iğ’«\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}). Theta bodies create a nested sequence of closed convex relaxations i.e., Tâ€‹H1â€‹(Iâ€‹(ğ’«))âŠ‡Tâ€‹H2â€‹(Iâ€‹(ğ’«))âŠ‡â‹¯âŠ‡convâ€‹(S)superset-of-or-equalsğ‘‡subscriptğ»1Iğ’«ğ‘‡subscriptğ»2Iğ’«superset-of-or-equalsâ‹¯superset-of-or-equalsconvğ‘†TH_{1}(\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}))\supseteq TH_{2}(\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}))\supseteq\dots\supseteq\texttt{conv}(S). We say a constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma is Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact if for any instance ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} of CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma) the ideal Iâ€‹(ğ’«)Iğ’«\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}) is Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact. The ideal Iâ€‹(ğ’«)Iğ’«\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}) is Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact if Tâ€‹Hkâ€‹(Iâ€‹(ğ’«))=convâ€‹(S)ğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜Iğ’«convğ‘†TH_{k}(\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P}))=\texttt{conv}(S). Zero-dimensional ideals are Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact for some finite kğ‘˜k .
An intriguing question is characterizing Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact constraint languages, for constant kğ‘˜k: Which constraint languages are Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact, for some constant kğ‘˜k?. This is analogous to LovÃ¡szâ€™s question [ref]40 where he asked: Which ideals in â„â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]â„subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\mathbb{R}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}] are Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact 111In fact, LovÃ¡szâ€™s asked which ideals in â„â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]â„subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\mathbb{R}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}] are (1,k)1ğ‘˜(1,k)-SOS. An ideal is (1,k)1ğ‘˜(1,k)-SOSÂ if every nonnegative linear polynomial on Sğ‘†S is kğ‘˜k-SOSÂ mod I. However, it turns out that a radical ideal in â„â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]â„subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\mathbb{R}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}] is (1,k)1ğ‘˜(1,k)-SOSÂ if and only if it is Tâ€‹Hkğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜TH_{k}-exact .. This question is partially answered in  for the case k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 from a completely different perspective. From algorithmic point of view, a natural question to ask is that for which constraint languages constructing theta bodies is a polynomial time task. For which constraint languages Î“Î“\Gamma the kğ‘˜k-th theta body Tâ€‹Hkâ€‹(Iâ€‹(ğ’«))ğ‘‡subscriptğ»ğ‘˜Iğ’«TH_{k}(\emph{{I}}(\mathcal{P})) is computable in polynomial time where ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} is an instance of CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma)? Here, we provide strong evidence that the polymorphisms of constraint languages might be the right notion that one should consider to address ProblemÂ 1.12. To construct the kğ‘˜k-th theta bodies it is sufficient to obtain a basis for the factor ring â„â€‹[x1,â€¦,xn]k/Iâ„subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘˜I\mathbb{R}[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}]_{k}/\emph{{I}} modulo ideal I  . Our result in Theorem 1.9 gives us such a luxury. While there are only very few problems for which efficient construction of theta bodies are known, we provide a unifying framework to study the computational aspects of theta bodies and, ultimately, making progress towards answering ProblemÂ 1.12. In particular, we present (rediscover) several positive results for problems such as Stable Set, Binary Matroids, H-Coloring, Min/Max Ones, and Strict CSPs.
